ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

PRIVATE EMPLOYMENT EXCHANGES
(Exploitation of job-seekers)


    1. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Minister for Labour and Welfare

Column: 1492

whether he is aware that some private employment exchanges in Singapore are exploiting employment seekers, and what does he propose to do about such concerns.

    Mr Lim Yew Hock: Sir, I am aware of one recent case in which four aggrieved employment seekers made a report to the police which led to the arrest and conviction of a man who had been operating a private employment agency. I have good reason to believe that although some private employment agencies are long established, there are others which exist only to exploit employment seekers. I am looking into the possibility of introducing new legislation under which private employment agencies can be effectively regulated. However, most of the bogus agencies which exploit the unemployed are mushroom growths, here today and gone tomorrow. The remedy in such cases is not new legislation but for the intended victims to make early reports to the police so that prompt action can be taken against them under the existing law.

LEGAL AID AND ADVICE ORDINANCE, 1956
(Implementation)


    2. Mr D. S. Marshall asked the Minister for Labour and Welfare whether he will make a statement on the implementation of the Legal Aid and Advice Ordinance, 1956.

    Mr Lim Yew Hock: Sir, the implementation of the Ordinance is dependent on the recruitment of the necessary staff, particularly of a Director of Legal Aid. Applications for various posts in Superscale Grade F of the legal service closed on 4th March and candidates have been interviewed by the Public Service Commission. It is expected that it will be possible to appoint one of the selected candidates to the post of Director of Legal Aid by the end of this month. As soon as this appointment has been made, implementation of the Ordinance will follow step by step.

NUCLEAR EXPLOSIONS OFF CHRISTMAS ISLAND


    3. Mr D. S. Marshall asked the Chief Secretary whether the Singapore Government has been consulted by, and/or has made representations to, the British Government with reference to the latter Government's intention to carry out nuclear explosions based on Christmas Island.

    Mr S. T. Stewart: The answer is no, Sir. The Member for Cairnhill will be aware that there are two Christmas Islands and that the tests are to be based on the one in the Pacific which is 6,600 miles from Singapore, and this is further from Singapore than the North Pole is. Perhaps the Member for Cairnhill is feeling a bit anxious because the Christmas Island in question is nearer to the Marshall Islands in the Pacific.

    Mr Marshall: The Member for Cairnhill is not aware, Sir, that distance has any particular effect in respect of the very grave disturbance to the human person by these explosions, and I would like to understand from the Chief Secretary whether he considers the 6,600 miles to be such adequate protection that there is to be no representation on behalf of the human beings who comprise this island's population? No answer -

DENTISTS' PETITION ON USE OF PATENT MEDICINES


    7. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Minister for Health what decision he has reached on the petition of Class "B" dentists about the use of patent medicine.

    Mr A. J. Braga: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have received no petition from Class "B" dentists about the use of patent medicines. There are, in fact, no such dentists as Class "B". Neither is there any restriction against the use of patent medicines outside the Poisons Ordinance. I had however received a petition from the Singapore Chinese Dentists Association asking that Division II dentists be allowed to use certain anti-biotics, sulfonilamides, penicillin cones and analgesics. A reply was sent to them on 10th September, 1956, stating that Government regretted that it did not propose to legislate for the withdrawal of the amended rules.

    The hon. Member may perhaps have in mind a petition addressed to the Chief Minister with a copy to me. I

Column: 1497

should like to make it clear that the Poisons Rules are specific in denying all Division II dentists the use of certain poisons that include anti-biotics, sulfonilamides, penicillin cones and analgesics. There is no restriction against the use of patent medicines.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Was there a copy of the petition, sent by the Singapore Chinese Dentists Association addressed to the Chief Minister, sent to the Minister for Health?

    Mr Braga: A petition from the Singapore Chinese Dentists Association was sent to me and there was another petition sent to the Chief Minister with a copy addressed to me.

NUCLEAR TESTS - EFFECT ON HEALTH AND FOOD


    8. Mr D. S. Marshall asked the Minister for Health whether he will make a statement as regards the possible effect on the health of the people of Singapore and their food supply of the proposed nuclear tests by the British Government based on Christmas Island.

    Mr Braga: Mr Speaker, Sir, I take it that what the hon. Member intends to ask is in reference to the proposed nuclear tests based on Christmas island by the British Government - an island which, as has already been pointed out, is 6,600 miles away and farther from Singapore than is the North Pole. I might add that there are several countries such as Australia, New Zealand. Hawaii, the Philippines and even the Californian coast of the United States of America which are far nearer to the centre of these experimental tests than is Singapore, and apparently no anxiety for the welfare of their peoples has yet been expressed by them. Russia has been exploding atom and hydrogen bombs at distances nearer to Singapore than is Christmas Island in the Pacific,

Column: 1498

and this question might well be addressed to them.

    As regards the danger of possible effect on the health of the people of Singapore and their food supply, I can do no better than quote the reply given by the Prime Minister in the House of Commons who would naturally have the advice of experts competent in these matters before he made the statement which I now quote from Hansard, 7th of June, 1956. The Prime Minister said:

    "These [tests] will take place during the first half of 1957 in a remote part of the Pacific Ocean. The explosions will take place far from any inhabited islands and the tests will be so arranged as to avoid danger to persons or property. The tests will be high air bursts which will not involve heavy fallout. All safety precautions will be taken in the light of our knowledge and of experience gained from the tests of other countries."

    On 1st April, 1957, the Prime Minister stated:

    "So far as our own tests are concerned, I have been asked to say that there will be no perceptible radiation outside the test area. This is my answer. I am satisfied that from the medical and biological point of view that the radiation effects of this explosion will be insignificant."

    And on 2nd April, 1957, the Prime Minister said:

    "Provided that the nuclear explosion takes place in areas remote from populated territories and an adequate danger area is declared for the period of the tests, any localised deposit of radio-active matter so diffused by the normal dispersal action of currents and winds as well as by the natural decay of the bulk of radio-activity emanating from the explosion, any possible danger to human health is negligible. Radio-active contamination of fish, marine plants and sea-weed can occur, only in the immediate vicinity of the explosion. The chances of any contamination going outside the danger area or continuing after the termination of the danger period is negligible in the case of tests conducted by the United Kingdom. There should be no contamination of fish from the high air bursts proposed for our forthcoming tests."

    Mr Marshall: The Minister has just come back from Japan, Sir. Is he aware of the deep anxiety of the millions of Japanese people in respect of these nuclear tests? Furthermore, Sir, I asked what effect on the food supply of Singapore will these tests have? Do we get fish from that area?

    Mr Marshall: He is our boss.

MILK PLANT OFFER BY AUSTRALIA
(White Paper)


    10. Mr D. S. Marshall asked the Minister for Commerce and Industry

Column: 1500

whether he will present to the House a White Paper on the Milk Plant offer by Australia to Singapore under the Colombo Plan.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: No, Sir. I do not consider the publication of a White Paper will serve any useful purpose since I have already issued a Press statement setting out the reasons why the Government has had to refuse the kind offer of the Australian Government.

    Mr Marshall: Is the Minister aware, Sir, that the people are deeply angered by his taking the food out of the mouths of babies and putting it into the mouths of pigs, and why cannot this House be entrusted with an examination in detail of the accounts which he says render the acceptance of the gift uneconomical?

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not aware that the people are deeply angered by my taking the food out of their mouths. I have not received any petition signed by the people of Singapore. If the Member for Cairnhill can claim to represent some people of Singapore, we on this side of the House can claim to represent probably 14 or 15 times more.

    As I have already stated, Sir, I have in a Press statement given all the reasons why we have had to refuse this offer by the Australian Government. A White Paper would only serve to bring to light the haste in which the offer was accepted in the first instance without proper reference to experts and to finding out the implications and financial involvement that would be brought about.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Is the Minister aware that the people of Singapore are greatly relieved that Australian dried milk producers are not going to make money out of Singapore by selling dried milk to that milk plant?

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am aware that the people of Singapore are greatly relieved because they are not going to be burdened with a $2 million recurrent expenditure a year. I am however not aware of the reasons given by the hon. Member.

Column: 1501



    Mr Marshall: is the Minister aware, Sir, or will he inform the House whether it is true that a commercial concern retailing milk in Singapore has been fighting the acceptance of this gift? And will he tell us why, since this gift was accepted under the Colombo Plan and a statement made in respect thereof in this Assembly, he is ashamed to produce a White Paper for the scrutiny of this House?

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: Sir, I am not ashamed to produce a White Paper. I do not consider it necessary to produce a White Paper. When the offer was accepted, the hon. Member, who was then the Minister for Commerce and Industry and the Chief Minister, did not put up a White Paper to this House at that time. This is a gift. The acceptance of the gift does not warrant the publication of a White Paper, and the refusal also does not, in my opinion, warrant the publication of a White Paper.

    As to the first part of his question - that a commercial firm has been fighting for us not to accept this gift - I am not aware of that fact, and I deny that there has been any pressure brought to bear on Government by any commercial firm or private enterprise to reject this offer. The offer has been refused purely on financial grounds. I do not consider that it is fair, when we have such heavy and urgent demands on our finances, to commit public revenue to the extent of a couple of million dollars per year on a project which I think will not have much demand. The milk which this scheme will turn out will not find much demand in Singapore.

SINGAPORE POLYTECHNIC (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

10.31 a.m.

    The Minister for Education (Mr Chew Swee Kee): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Singapore Polytechnic Ordinance was an Ordinance to provide for the establishment of the Singapore Polytechnic and for matters connected therewith. When that Ordinance was drafted, the

Column: 1505

authorities in Singapore knew little of the workings of such institutions and naturally sought experience from other territories where the experience of those territories themselves were setting up establishments of the same kind and therefore had little to offer. But conditions elsewhere were not the same as those in Singapore nor was it possible to foresee at that time the changes which only experience of working under the terms of the Ordinance would show to be necessary. The present Ordinance sufficed only to establish the Board of Governors to enable them and the Board to plan the buildings and to recruit key members of the staff but it has become increasingly apparent that amendments are necessary if the Board is to continue to work efficiently.

    The amendments which this Bill seeks to make are listed very clearly and simply in the Explanatory Note and I think it is unnecessary for me to dwell in detail upon them. I would merely mention that the work of the Board is at present handicapped because all decisions had to be taken at full meetings of the Board. It is important especially that provision should be made for the constitution of sub-committees to which certain powers of the Board could be delegated. This provision is made in clause 3 of the Bill which by an amendment to section 5 of the original Ordinance gives the Board the power to make the necessary by-laws. Sir, I move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Question proposed.

10.33 a.m.

    Mr John Ede (Tanglin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have only one point I wish to make regarding this Bill. At first sight, it would appear to be a matter of detail but if we take similar provisions in the Education Bill into account, it is clearly a matter of Government policy. I refer to the provisions to revoke appointments in paragraphs (e) and (f) of clause 2. Paragraph (e) reads:

    "The Chairman and other members appointed by the Minister under subsection (2) of this section shall, unless the Minister shall otherwise direct, hold office for a period of

Column: 1506

four years and shall be re-eligible for reappointment:

    Provided that the Minister may at any time revoke such appointment."

There is a similar provision under paragraph (f) for persons or bodies appointing members to the Board.

    Sir, we can see no good reason why appointments once made for a period of four years should be subject to revocation at any time. Once an appointment is made, the person so appointed, should feel that he can settle down and do the job of work for which he has been appointed. It is a system on which we work in this House. However much Members on this side may regret that the present Government can remain in office for four years, the Government is entitled to that period and we feel that the same sense of stability should be given to members of the Board. I am aware that the Explanatory Note 2 (b) states:

    "Amendments to section 4 provide, for appointing bodies to have the power to revoke the appointments of members of the Board who have not satisfactorily represented their interests."

Now, whether or not my hon. Friend the Minister for Education in the last two years has satisfactorily represented the interests of his electorate is a matter of opinion but he is entitled to sit in this House for better or for worse for a further period of two years. I see no reason why the Chairman of the Board should not be equally immune from summary dismissal. The proviso implies that if the Chairman does not toe the Minister's line, he could be sacked and it also implies that the Minister has poor confidence in his own selection. Furthermore, if there were a general election and a change of government, the Chairman could be dismissed and replaced by some favourite of the new Minister. The same argument applies to the appointments made by the various bodies and conditions would arise which could seriously affect the smooth running of the Polytechnic and an educational institution should be outside the play of politics.

    Sir, these are dangerous provisos. If it is felt that there is an argument against appointments for four years, then let us reduce them to, say, three

Column: 1507

years but do not let us run the risk of making these appointments open to the abuse of whims, factions and patronage.

10.37 a.m.
